Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Mechanisms of Freshwater Exchange Across the East Greenland Shelf
Award.AbstractNarration:
Freshwater flowing out of the Arctic and from Greenland ice melt has the potential to modulate or even shut down deep convection in the sub-polar North Atlantic. The processes that control this exchange, and how they depend on external factors such as wind and outflow from the Arctic, are not well known and are not well resolved in basin-scale and climate models. Better understanding of the freshwater budget on the shelf, and how these waters get into the deep ocean interior, is essential to improve climate models and understand how the ocean will respond to a changing climate. The dynamically-based diagnostics planned in this project using a hierarchy of numerical ocean circulation models will also inform on mechanisms, locations, and times of exchange in other sensitive areas, such as the east coast of Labrador. Findings from the project will be used in undergraduate and graduate classes. Undergraduate students supported by the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution Summer Student Fellowship program and assisted by graduate students will gain research experience. Material from the project will also be used in a textbook on ocean circulation. A graduate student will be trained in physical oceanography, geophysical fluid dynamics, and ocean modeling at Johns Hopkins University.

The exchange of freshwater between the east Greenland shelf and the interior of the sub-polar North Atlantic and Nordic Seas is a key element in the maintenance and variability of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) and its sensitivity to changes in atmospheric forcing and freshwater outflow from the Arctic Ocean. A realistic, very high resolution, regional model of the east Greenland shelf and adjacent deep ocean will be combined with idealized, process oriented models and in-situ observations to identify the strength, mechanisms, and sensitivity of this exchange. Processes likely important for this cross-shelf exchange include: surface and bottom Ekman layers; nonlinear eddy fluxes; local and remote wind-forcing; and wind-driven sea ice. The exchange will be diagnosed in a series of realistic model runs. Experiments will be designed with the idealized model to isolate the relevant processes for further study and understanding, and comparisons will be made with in-situ mooring and hydrographic observations and remotely sensed sea ice data. The main goal of the project is to reach a basic understanding of what controls the flux of freshwater from the shelf to the basin interior and how it depends on external forcing (wind, outflow from the Arctic, Greenland runoff) and environmental conditions such as bottom bathymetry and the ambient stratification.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied the flow of seawater east of Greenland. The currents in this area form a vital element of the ocean current system of the North Atlantic Ocean. They are important for climate and fisheries, among other reasons. The project was motivated by the widespread changes in the Arctic Ocean, such as loss of summer time sea ice in the last 30 years and the associated decrease in seawater salinity. These changes are expected to affect the North Atlantic Ocean, primarily as the altered water passes east of Greenland. This may already be happening, but it is unclear because knowledge and understanding of these currents is limited.

The Johns Hopkins University part of this collaborative project used a realistic numerical model of the ocean currents, temperatures, and salinities. First we compared it carefully to the available measurements from the real ocean to judge its accuracy. Then we used the model to fill the gaps in the sparse measurements. This framework allowed us to explore how the exchange in the shallow gap between Greenland and Iceland occurs. This exchange is the single strongest component of the flow east of Greenland. We studied the nature of intense fluctuations in the currents passing through the gap, how they evolve, and where they come from. We studied the dynamical processes associated with the fluctuations to understand their basic nature. The results from this research have advanced understanding of the ocean circulation in this area, which facilitates monitoring of the changing ocean state arriving from the Arctic Ocean. They can also be applied to other sea straits.

In related work, we studied the changing surface salinity in the oceans around Greenland on a larger geographic scale. Using data from autonomous floating instruments, we found that the salinity is decreasing in the last 15 years, as in the Arctic. The reasons for the freshening are unclear. There might be a connection to the Arctic freshening, but more likely is that changes in the North Atlantic Ocean are responsible. For instance, the influence of the salty Gulf Stream may have diminished, causing freshening near Greenland.

The Intellectual Merit of the project concerns the scientific value of improved knowledge and understanding of the ocean circulation in this area. Freshwater flowing out of the Arctic and from melting of the Greenland Ice Sheet has the potential to influence the currents in the North Atlantic Ocean, with consequences for climate in the region. This project produced several peer-reviewed scientific papers for physical oceanographers, climate scientists, and fisheries experts. It also developed new high-accuracy numerical models of the currents and software infrastructure to analyze the results. This publicly-available infrastructure facilitated collaboration, and will continue to do so in the future.

The Broader Impacts of the projects concern the oceanographic and climate science communities. The improved knowledge and understanding of the ocean currents near Greenland will guide construction of better climate models that are used to project climate change. Material from the project has been used in undergraduate and graduate classes at Johns Hopkins University. Material from the project has also been used in a new textbook on ocean circulation co-written by the project leader. Two PhD students have been trained in physical oceanography, geophysical fluid dynamics, and ocean modeling. They performed much of the research themselves and they intend to pursue careers in marine science, education, and/or research.
